PEN/Newman's Own
SPJ 1st Amendment
Zenger Award | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Vanessa Leggett''' (née '''Levrier'''; born May 18, 1968) is a freelance journalist, author, lecturer and [[First Amendment]] advocate who was jailed by the [[U.S. Justice Department]] for 168 days for protecting sources and research notes for an independent book about a federal murder-for-hire case. It is the longest contempt-of-court imprisonment of a journalist in [[United States]] history for protecting sources.{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/books/2002-02-22/84702/|title=True Crime and Punishment|author=|date=|website=The Austin Chronicle}} ==Early life and education== Leggett, the daughter of a Houston oil trader, earned her bachelor's degree in English and a master's degree in liberal arts from the [[University of St. Thomas (Texas)]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/08/11/us/public-lives-when-a-writer-is-punished-for-not-being-an-author.html|title=When a Writer Is Punished for Not Being an Author|author=|date=11 August 2001|website=The New York Times}} ==Case history== In April 1997, the body of [[Houston, Texas]], socialite [[Doris Angleton]] was discovered in her home. She died from 13 gunshot wounds to her face and chest. At the time of the death, her twin daughters and husband, Robert Angleton, a millionaire and former bookie,http://www.newseuminstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Jailed-subpoenaed-timeline1.pdf were at a softball game.{{cite web|url=http://www.houstonpress.com/news/murder-she-testified-6561285|title=Murder, She Testified|first=Steve|last=McVicker|date=19 July 2001|website=Houston Press}} Leggett researched the case for five years. In 1998, in a jailhouse interview of Roger Angleton, a suspect in a murder-for-hire plot. Leggett compiled notes and hours of audio tape that reportedly detailed how Roger's brother Robert hired him to murder his brother's wife Doris. The interviews occurred just before Roger's suicide in his Harris County jail cell and before Robert's trial.{{cite web|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/articles/oh-brother/|title=Oh, Brother|author=|date=31 May 1998|website=texasmonthly.com}} On June 19, 2001, U.S. District Judge [[Melinda Harmon]] ordered Leggett to appear in court the next day with her notes and tapes for a book she was researching about the murder. The order was in response to a grand jury that had convened to investigate the possibility of filing federal murder charges against the victim's husband, Robert Angleton.{{cite web|url=http://corporate.findlaw.com/litigation-disputes/vanessa-leggett-serves-maximum-jail-time-first-amendment-based.html|title=Vanessa Leggett Serves Maximum Jail Time, First Amendment-Based Reporter's Privilege Under {{Sic|Sei|ge|hide=y}} |author=|date=|publisher=FindLaw}} Leggett, appearing in court on June 20, 2001, refused to turn over her notes, citing [[freedom of the press]]. She was then held in civil contempt of court and jailed by the [[U.S. Justice Department]] for refusing to turn over her notes. News organizations, publications and journalists championed Leggett's case, advocating that the public interest requires protecting journalists in Leggett's position.http://www.nyujlpp.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/Jennifer-Elrod-Protecting-Journalists-from-Compelled-Disclosures-A-Proposal-for-a-Federal-Statue.pdf ''[[The New York Times]]'' called Leggett's incarceration "a brazen assault on 1st Amendment values and the public interest in a free press."{{cite web|url=https://charlierose.com/videos/843|title=Vanessa Leggett - Charlie Rose|author=|date=|publisher=}} The [[Center for Individual Freedom]] filed an amicus brief in support of Leggett's petition asking the U.S. Supreme Court to hear her case. The center also contributed to her legal defense fund.{{cite web|url=http://www.cfif.org/htdocs/legal_issues/legal_activities/amicus_briefs/center_files_brief.htm|title=Center Files Brief on Behalf of Vanessa Leggett|first=Copyright: Unless provided otherwise, all materials and contents of this website are copyrighted and certain logos, slogans and other marks are protected under trademark laws. All rights are reserved under Title 17 of the U.S. Code and transmission or reproduction of the protected items requires the written permission of the Center for Individual Freedom or the applicable copyright|last=owner.|date=|website=www.cfif.org}} In addition, the [[Society of Professional Journalists]], through its Legal Defense Fund, paid half of Leggett's legal expenses.{{cite web|url=https://www.spj.org/quill_issue.asp?ref=242|title=Quill: From the Editor: Leggett case is part of a larger battle - Society of Professional Journalists - Improving and protecting journalism since 1909|author=|date=|website=www.spj.org}} She was released on January 4, 2002, after serving the maximum sentence,{{cite web|url=http://corporate.findlaw.com/litigation-disputes/vanessa-leggett-serves-maximum-jail-time-first-amendment-based.html|title=Vanessa Leggett Serves Maximum Jail Time, First Amendment-Based Reporter's Privilege Under {{sic|Sei|ge|hide=y}} |author=|date=|website=findlaw.com}} from the [[Federal Detention Center, Houston|Houston Federal Detention Center]] after 168 days of incarceration on the civil contempt charge when the federal grand jury completed its term.{{cite web|url=http://www.rcfp.org/browse-media-law-resources/news/vanessa-leggett-released-jail-after-168-days|title=Vanessa Leggett released from jail after 168 days - Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press|author=|date=26 October 2011|website=www.rcfp.org}} Leggett said to reporters as she walked out of jail, "This is not so much about me. It's about the public's right to a free and independent press."{{cite web|url=http://supreme.findlaw.com/legal-commentary/who-counts-as-a-journalist-for-first-amendment-purposes.html|title=Who Counts As A Journalist, For First Amendment Purposes? - FindLaw|author=|date=|website=Findlaw}} After her release, Leggett, appearing on the ''[[Charlie Rose (TV series)|Charlie Rose]]'' show in April 2004, said, "(My sources) had taken a chance by cooperating with me and giving me information and trusting me with that information. And I felt obligated to honor that. When I realized that underlying this was an assault on the 1st Amendment, it became something much larger than just my sources or just my book. It was about protecting the free flow of information to the public." ==Career== Leggett signed a book contract in 2002 with [[Crown Publishers]] about the Angleton murder for a reported $600,000 advance.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/qampa-vanessa-leggetts-book-deal-145483|title=Q&Amp;A: Vanessa Leggett's Book Deal|author=|date=1 May 2002|website=newsweek.com}} She continued her career as a freelance writer, including a long-form first-person account for ''[[Texas Monthly]]'' about her 5-1/2 months behind bars at the [[Federal Detention Center]] in Houston,{{cite web|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/articles/doing-time/|title=Doing Time|author=|date=30 June 2002|website=texasmonthly.com}} as well as conducting an exclusive interview in 2015 for ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' magazine with accused serial killer [[Robert Durst]].{{cite web|url=http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/a35948/robert-durst-croissants-lunch/|title=My Lunch With Robert Durst|author=|date=25 June 2015|publisher=Esquire}} ===Criminal justice lecturer=== From 1995 to 2016, Leggett taught literature, criminology and writing courses at the [[University of Houston-Downtown]],{{cite web|url=https://columns.wlu.edu/jailed-reporter-vanessa-leggett-to-give-keynote-for-wls-ethics-institute/|title=Jailed Reporter Vanessa Leggett to Give Keynote for W&L's Ethics Institute|author=|date=24 October 2007|website=wlu.edu}} including at the university's Criminal Justice Training Center, where she taught Texas police recruits and lectured veteran homicide investigators.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/oct/29/news/mn-62991|title=In Lockup, Crime Writer Ponders Strange Plot Twist|first=MIKE|last=ANTON|date=29 October 2001|publisher=|via=LA Times}} In 2002, she headlined with journalist [[Bob Woodward]] at the 23rd Annual Washington Writers Conference held at the [[National Press Club]]. At the same event, Leggett was given the [[Washington Independent Writers]]' President's Award. In addition, the Washington Independent Writers' Legal and Educational Fund presented Leggett with a $1,000 check for her stand in support of the First Amendment.{{cite web|url=http://h-net.msu.edu/cgi-bin/logbrowse.pl?trx=vx&list=jhistory&month=0205&week=b&msg=IU7LQm58TIDrvwB0AbKGyg&user=&pw|title=H-Net Discussion Networks - Vanessa Leggett, Bob Woodward, WIW Conference, May 17–18|author=|date=|website=h-net.msu.edu}} She also lectured at the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the Swedish National Board of Forensic Medicine, and the Netherlands Institute for the Study of Crime and Law Enforcement.{{cite web|url=https://news.uhd.edu/2016/05/31/criminal-justice-lecturer-presents-at-international-conference/|title=Criminal Justice Lecturer Presents at International Conference|first=|last=UHD|date=31 May 2016|website=uhd.edu}} She gave the keynote address at the Institute for Ethics and Journalism's 2007 conference, which was sponsored by the [[Knight Foundation]]'s Program in Journalism Ethics and [[Washington and Lee University]]'s department of journalism and mass communications. In 2015, she sat on the First Amendment Advocacy panel at the National Press Club and discussed the need for stronger legal protections for journalists.{{cite web|url=http://www.press.org/news-multimedia/news/true-crime-novelist-jailed-protecting-sources-discuss-experience-june-1|title=True crime novelist, jailed for protecting sources, to discuss experience, June 1|author=|date=8 May 2015|website=National Press Club}} And in 2016, she spoke at the International Academy of Investigative Psychology's annual conference at [[John Jay College of Criminal Justice]].{{cite web|url=https://news.uhd.edu/2016/05/31/criminal-justice-lecturer-presents-at-international-conference/|title=Criminal Justice Lecturer Presents at International Conference|first=|last=UHD|date=31 May 2016|website=uhd.edu}} She has also given talks to the [[New York City Bar Association]] and the [[FBI Academy]]'s Behavioral Science Unit. == Books == The [[FBI Academy]], [[U.S. Department of Justice]], released two books by Leggett, ''The Varieties of Homicide and its Research'', published in 1999,{{cite web|url=http://www.davekopel.com/NRO/2001/Redefining-Justice.htm|title=Redefining Justice|author=|date=|website=www.davekopel.com}}http://www.guncite.com/varieties_homicide_research and ''The Diversity of Homicide'', co-authored by Leggett, Paul Blackman and John Jarvis, published in 2000.{{cite web|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.197.945&rep=rep1&type=pdf|title=Download Limit Exceeded|author=|date=|website=citeseerx.ist.psu.edu}} ==Awards== *Washington Independent Writers gave Legget the President's Award in 2002. *The [[PEN American Center]] awarded her the 2002 PEN/Newman's Own First Amendment Award, with one judge stating that her case was "especially inspiring" because she "fought her battle without the backing of a newspaper or media organization."{{cite web|url=https://pen.org/press-release/vanessa-leggett-to-receive-2002-pennewmans-own-first-amendment-award/|title=Vanessa Leggett to receive 2002 PEN/Newman's Own First Amendment Award - PEN America|author=|date=|publisher=}} *The Society of Professional Journalists awarded Leggett its 2002 First Amendment Award for refusing to turn over her notes to authorities.{{cite web|url=https://www.spj.org/quill_issue.asp?ref=383|title=Quill: Awards from the Society - Society of Professional Journalists - Improving and protecting journalism since 1909|author=|date=|website=www.spj.org}} *The [[University of Arizona]] [[Journalism School|School of Journalism]] awarded Leggett the 2003 Zenger Award for Press Freedom. ==Personal life== She is married to Doak Leggett.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/2001/12/15/for-jailed-writer-prison-time-is-study-in-ethics-experience/1e341262-7dba-42c3-a000-ea102dcf63e2/|title=For Jailed Writer, Prison Times is Study in Ethics, Experience|author=Paul Duggan|date=December 15, 2001|website=www.washingtonpost.com}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|9173713}} *[http://www.celebritytalentpromotions.com/speaker/vanessa-leggett.php Vanessa Leggett speaker profile] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leggett, Vanessa}} [[Category:1968 births]] women writers]] [[Category:American women journalists]] [[Category:American producers]] [[Category:American women television journalists]] [[Category:Women crime writers]]

A '''visual dictionary''' is a [[dictionary]] that primarily uses pictures to illustrate the meaning of [[word]]s. Visual dictionaries are often organized by themes, instead of being an [[alphabetical]] list of words. For each theme, an image is labeled with the correct word to identify each component of the item in question. Visual dictionaries can be [[monolingual]] or [[multilingual]], providing the names of items in several [[language]]s. An index of all defined words is usually included to assist finding the correct illustration that defines the word.
Some international visual dictionary publishers include [[Oxford University Press]], [[QA International]] and [[Dorling Kindersley]].
==See also== *[[Picture dictionary]] *[[Knowledge visualization]] *[[Visual language]]
==External links== *[http://www.spinfold.com/category/visual-dictionary/ Visual Dictionary – SpinFold] *[http://visual.merriam-webster.com/ Visual Thematic Dictionary – Merriam Webster] *[http://www.snappywords.com Visual Net Meaning Dictionary – Snappy Words] *[http://www.vocabahead.com Visual Video Vocabulary – VocabAhead]
{{Lexicography}}

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Computer benchmarks]] to [[Category:Benchmarks (computing)]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Speed]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
The '''Yahoo! Cloud Serving Benchmark''' (YCSB) is an open-source specification and program suite for evaluating retrieval and maintenance capabilities of computer programs. It is often used to compare relative performance of [[NoSQL]] database management systems.
The original benchmark was developed by workers in the research division of [[Yahoo!]] who released it in 2010 with the stated goal of "facilitating performance comparisons of the new generation of cloud data serving systems", particularly for transaction-processing workloads which differed from ones measured by benchmarks designed for more traditional database management systems. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cs.duke.edu/courses/fall13/cps296.4/838-CloudPapers/ycsb.pdf|title=Benchmarking cloud serving systems with YCSB|last=Cooper|first=Brian F|date=|website=|publisher=Yahoo Research|access-date=|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
YCSB was contrasted with the TPC-H benchmark from the [[Transaction Processing Performance Council]], with YCSB being called a [[big data]] benchmark while TPC-H is a [[decision support system]] benchmark.<ref>{{cite web |author= Melyssa Barata, Jorge Bernadino and Pedro Furtado |date= June 27, 2014 |title= YCSB and TPC-H: Big Data and Decision Support Benchmarks |publisher= IEEE |work= 2014 International Congress on Big Data |url= http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/login.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6906872&url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fxpls%2Fabs_all.jsp%3Farnumber%3D6906872|display-authors=etal |doi= 10.1109/BigData.Congress.2014.128 }}</ref>
YCSB was used by DBMS vendors for "benchmark marketing".<ref>{{cite web |title= YCSB benchmark notes |last= Monash |first= Curt |url= http://www.dbms2.com/2013/01/17/ycsb-benchmark-notes |publisher= Monash Research}}</ref> It has been used in scholarly or tutorial discussions, particularly for [[Apache HBase]].<ref>{{cite web |title= YCSB+T: Benchmarking web-scale transactional databases |last1= Dey |first1= Akon |last2= Nambiar |first2= Raghunath |publisher= IEEE |url= http://www.computer.org/csdl/proceedings/icdew/2014/3481/00/06818330.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= HBase Administration Cookbook |last= Jiang |first=Lifeng |year= 2012 |publisher= Packt Publishing |url= https://www.safaribooksonline.com/library/view/hbase-administration-cookbook/9781849517140/ch09s02.html}}</ref> It has been used for multiple-product comparisons by industry observers such as [[Network World]] (comparing [[Apache Cassandra|Cassandra]], [[MongoDB]], and [[Riak]]),<ref>{{cite web |last= Bushik |first= Sergey |title= A vendor-independent comparison of NoSQL databases |url= http://www.networkworld.com/article/2160905/tech-primers/a-vendor-independent-comparison-of-nosql-databases--cassandra--hbase--mongodb--riak.html |publisher= Network World}}</ref> Thumbtack Technologies (comparing [[Aerospike database|Aerospike]], Cassandra, [[Couchbase]], and MongoDB),<ref>{{cite web | title=NoSQL Benchmark Compares Aerospike, Cassandra, Couchbase and MongoDB |url= http://www.infoq.com/news/2013/04/NoSQL-Benchmark |first=Avram |last= Abel |publisher= InfoQ}}</ref> and the [[Polytechnic Institute]] and [[University of Coimbra]] (comparing Cassandra, HBase, [[Elasticsearch]], MongoDB, [[Oracle NoSQL Database|Oracle NoSQL]], [[OrientDB]], [[Redis]], Scalaris, [[Tarantool]], and [[Voldemort (distributed data store)|Voldemort]]).<ref>{{cite web |title= Experimental Evaluation of NoSQL Databases |last1= Abramova |first1= Veronika |last2=Bernardino |first2=Jorge |last3=Furtado |first3=Pedro |publisher= International Journal of Database Management Systems |url= http://airccse.org/journal/ijdms/papers/6314ijdms01.pdf}}</ref> [[SanDisk Corporation]] published results measured on the [[Oracle NoSQL Database]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Oracle NoSQL Database Cluster YCSB Testing with Fusion ioMemory Storage |url= https://www.sandisk.com/content/dam/sandisk-main/en_us/assets/resources/enterprise/white-papers/oracle-nosql-cluster-ycsb-testing-with-fusion-iomemory.pdf |date= June 15, 2016 |accessdate= September 20, 2016 }}</ref>
